stream_context.summary: Kaze Emanuar, joined by guest developer Sauraen, conducted a live, deep-dive debugging session to diagnose and solve a major performance regression with the new F3DEX3 microcode in 'Return to Yoshi's Island'. The stream involved extensive technical discussion, live assembly coding, and systematic testing, which ultimately uncovered a new, unresolved performance mystery. Kaze also worked on modeling assets for a Mario Kart 64-themed retro level.

development_findings.summary: The core technical problem is that the new F3DEX3 microcode, while speeding up the RDP (graphics processor), slows down the RSP (co-processor) more than anticipated. This trade-off is failing because Kaze's game is already highly optimized, making the RSP the new bottleneck.
development_findings.quote: There's not a lot of headroom to make the RSP go slower and make the RDP go faster.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is not using point lights, a key feature F3DEX3 was optimized for. He fakes the effect with vertex colors computed on the CPU to ensure broad compatibility, especially with emulators.
development_findings.quote: Are you ever planning to use point lights in RTYI? No, absolutely not because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

development_findings.summary: Sauraen explains that F3DEX3's architecture is more straightforward but requires more matrix multiplications per vertex for lighting compared to F3DEX2, which should make it slower for Kaze's use case (many directional lights, no point lights).
development_findings.quote: The vertex processing takes like way longer in EX2 in RSP time... wait, EX3. No, EX2... what the hell.

development_findings.summary: An early profiling bug in Kaze's setup reported the RSP task time as 8ms when it was actually 16ms, which led Sauraen to incorrectly believe there was plenty of performance headroom.

Live debugging with custom counters revealed that vertex and triangle processing account for ~18ms of the 27ms RSP task time. There is a mysterious 9ms of unexplained processing time that is the source of the performance issue.
development_findings.quote: So this should be you know 9.8 milliseconds plus 8.2 milliseconds is like 18.1 milliseconds... but it's actually like another 9 milliseconds. Yeah, something's up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing 'retro pipes' in each level that reference classic games from the N64 era. The stream showed work on a Kalamari Desert (from Mario Kart 64) area.
Kaze demonstrates how he fakes the effect of point lights, such as one inside a fire, by dynamically creating a directional light source aimed from the fire's position.
development_findings.quote: We just use a directional light like that.

development_findings.summary: Switching to F3DEX3 broke Mario's lighting because it uses a new GBI (graphics binary interface) that requires code changes to be compatible.
development_findings.quote: I need to update the way I do lighting before they will work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a design philosophy focused on preserving the core gameplay of Mario 64, avoiding features like a drivable kart that would fundamentally change the experience.
context_findings.quote: It kind of feels like, oh, you like Mario 64. Well, fuck you. Here's Mario Kart. I don't want that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware that his romhacks are sold on physical cartridges by third parties without his consent or financial benefit, and he views it as an unavoidable part of the scene.
context_findings.quote: you gotta have some tolerance for that in order to be in this

context_findings.summary: Kaze states a preference for developing directly for original hardware, but acknowledges that emulator performance is a practical constraint he must consider.
context_findings.quote: I just want to make my N64 game. Ideally, I wouldn't have to deal with emulators at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges the security risks of using the outdated Project 64 1.6 emulator but continues to use it for his own development due to convenience and familiarity.
context_findings.quote: You shouldn't use it if you're gonna play someone else's romhack because they can just put malware in there, but I have no reason to get parallel because I'm not gonna play anyone else's.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's partner, Zeina, is present and watching the stream, as indicated by her message in the chat.
Kaze reveals that development on a 'Bowser magician' character has been stalled for years due to an unreliable community collaborator, souring him on open calls for help.
context_findings.quote: Someone offered to do the animations in 2021 and they kept saying I'll do it, I'll do it, I'll do it and then they didn't do it. And that's why you don't do call-ups.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the stream chat, showing support.
zeina.quote: Yo, we got a sup from Zeina.

key_stories.title: The F3DEX3 Performance Mystery
key_stories.summary: Kaze and guest developer Sauraen conducted a deep-dive technical investigation to solve a critical performance regression caused by the new F3DEX3 microcode. Through a methodical process of elimination and live-coding new diagnostic tools, they debunked their initial hypothesis and uncovered a deeper, more mysterious performance bug that is now the primary focus.
key_stories.challenge: The new F3DEX3 microcode, intended to be a performance upgrade, was making 'Return to Yoshi's Island' run significantly slower, threatening a key technical advancement for the project.
key_stories.process: Kaze and F3DEX3 developer Sauraen collaborated on a live debugging session. They compared performance against older microcode versions, tested hypotheses by disabling the entire lighting system, and ultimately live-coded new performance counters into the microcode itself to isolate the time spent on vertex vs. triangle processing.
key_stories.outcome: The initial theories were disproven. Custom performance counters revealed that while vertex processing was slower, an additional, unexplained 9 milliseconds of RSP time was the true culprit. The issue remains unsolved, with Sauraen taking the new data to investigate further offline.
key_stories.key_quote: The vertex processing is slower but like that's not all that's happening here, something else is taking a ton of time.

open_questions.context: The live debugging session with Sauraen concluded that there's a ~9ms performance gap in the RSP task time that isn't explained by vertex or triangle processing.
